UI_visible_response: Read 18 web pagesView Page DetailsThe "Jasmine Revolution" refers to the popular uprising in Tunisia that took place from December 17, 2010, to January 14, 2011. It was triggered by the self-immolation of Mohamed Bouazizi, a 26-year-old street vendor, who set himself on fire to protest against government corruption and economic hardship. His act became a symbol of the widespread discontent among Tunisians regarding unemployment, poverty, and political repression under President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali.The protests quickly spread throughout the country, leading to violent clashes with police and the eventual ousting of Ben Ali, who had ruled Tunisia for 23 years. The revolution not only led to the fall of Ben Ali's regime but also inspired similar uprisings across the Middle East and North Africa, collectively known as the Arab Spring.In the aftermath of the Jasmine Revolution, Tunisia embarked on a path towards democratic transition. A new constitution was drafted and adopted in January 2014, and the country held its first free elections. Tunisia is often cited as the only success story of the Arab Spring, as it managed to transition from authoritarianism to a more democratic system.CopyTry AgainShare
traffic_visible_response: The "Jasmine Revolution" refers to the popular uprising in Tunisia that took place from December 17, 2010, to January 14, 2011[^7^]. It was triggered by the self-immolation of Mohamed Bouazizi, a 26-year-old street vendor, who set himself on fire to protest against government corruption and economic hardship[^1^][^3^]. His act became a symbol of the widespread discontent among Tunisians regarding unemployment, poverty, and political repression under President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali[^1^][^7^].The protests quickly spread throughout the country, leading to violent clashes with police and the eventual ousting of Ben Ali, who had ruled Tunisia for 23 years[^1^][^3^]. The revolution not only led to the fall of Ben Ali's regime but also inspired similar uprisings across the Middle East and North Africa, collectively known as the Arab Spring[^1^][^2^].In the aftermath of the Jasmine Revolution, Tunisia embarked on a path towards democratic transition. A new constitution was drafted and adopted in January 2014, and the country held its first free elections[^2^][^7^]. Tunisia is often cited as the only success story of the Arab Spring, as it managed to transition from authoritarianism to a more democratic system[^2^].
